message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lesion suggests Paget disease of the breast, which is an uncommon form of breast cancer. A punch biopsy of the nipple is needed to confirm the diagnosis and exclude invasive carcinoma. Bilateral mammography is necessary to rule out other possible breast lesions. Ultrasound and MRI are not the first line of investigation in this case. Oral corticosteroids are not indicated for Paget disease of the breast.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The erythematous, scaly lesion involving the left breast nipple-areolar complex with weeping drainage suggests Paget disease of the nipple. A punch biopsy of the nipple should be performed to confirm the diagnosis followed by bilateral mammography. Other options, including breast ultrasound and MRI, may be useful for further evaluation but are not the next immediate step. Corticosteroids may provide symptomatic relief but will not diagnose or treat the underlying condition.

We refer to UpToDate articles on medicine for help. The erythematous, scaly lesion with weeping drainage could be indicative of Paget disease of the nipple or inflammatory breast cancer, which require biopsy for diagnosis. Bilateral breast ultrasound or MRI may be ordered later to assess for possible multifocal disease. Corticosteroids are not indicated as the first step in management.

We refer to a medical website for help. Given the characteristics of the lesion, which involves the nipple-areolar complex with weeping drainage, the next step would be punch biopsy of the nipple followed by bilateral mammography. Bilateral breast ultrasound may be considered if there is suspicion of multiple lesions or if the biopsy is inconclusive. Oral corticosteroids and left breast MRI are not the next necessary steps in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of the lesion suggest Paget’s disease of the breast, which can be confirmed with a punch biopsy of the nipple followed by bilateral mammography. Bilateral breast ultrasound, left breast MRI, and oral corticosteroids are not useful for diagnosing or managing Paget’s disease of the breast.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a suspicious breast lesion with weeping drainage, which suggests Paget disease of the breast. A punch biopsy of the nipple is the standard diagnostic approach for this condition, followed by bilateral mammography. Ultrasound or MRI may be used for further evaluation but are not the first-line diagnostic approach. Oral corticosteroids are not indicated for Paget disease of the breast.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a scaly lesion involving the nipple-areolar complex with weeping drainage is a concerning symptom that requires further investigation. A punch biopsy of the nipple followed by bilateral mammography would be the most appropriate next step in the patient’s management. Bilateral breast ultrasound or left breast MRI would not be the first-line imaging modality in this scenario. Oral corticosteroids may provide symptomatic relief but would not address the underlying pathology.

We refer to the American Cancer Society guidelines for breast cancer screening for help. The presentation of the lesion is concerning for breast cancer, especially Paget disease of the nipple. Therefore, the next step in management is to perform a punch biopsy of the nipple followed by bilateral mammography to evaluate for any additional abnormalities. Bilateral breast ultrasound or MRI may also be performed as needed, but mammography and biopsy are the first steps. Oral corticosteroids are not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of an erythematous, scaly lesion involving the nipple-areolar complex with weeping drainage raises suspicion of Paget’s disease of the breast, which is a type of breast cancer. A punch biopsy of the nipple is necessary to confirm the diagnosis, followed by bilateral mammography to evaluate for any other suspicious areas. Ultrasound and MRI may be useful in further evaluation and staging, but biopsy and mammography are the initial steps in management. Oral corticosteroids are not indicated for this condition.

We refer to the American Cancer Society's guidelines for breast cancer screening for help. The appearance of the lesion and its location on the nipple-areolar complex raises concern for Paget’s disease of the breast, which has a high association with underlying ductal carcinoma in situ or invasive breast cancer. Therefore, a punch biopsy of the nipple should be performed to establish a definitive diagnosis, followed by bilateral mammography to evaluate for other areas of concern. A breast ultrasound or MRI may also be considered based on the results of the biopsy and mammogram. Oral corticosteroids would not be appropriate for this condition.
